title: When will China next deploy a deep sea oil rig in another country's exclusive economic zone (EEZ) without that country's permission?
preds:
Looking back on it, it’s possible that all the attention on North Korea gave China the opportunity to continue its construction on disputed islands with minimal attention. Maybe an event such as moving an oil rig into another country’s EEZ would’ve put the spotlight back on to China (given the media storm after the event in 2014) which would have highlighted the issue of the disputed islands, much to China’s disadvantage. 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-southchinasea/chinese-report-says-south-china-sea-islands-expanded-reasonably-idUSKBN1EJ02J
https://www.ft.com/content/5817d3de-e564-11e7-97e2-916d4fbac0da
I doubt anything will happen in the next week.
I doubt anything will happen in the next week.

“.... only in one case did a newly acquired capability allow China to move. This was the oil rig incident, when China dispatched its most advanced and newly acquired deep water drilling technology, and it protected the operation with newly unified and strengthened paramilitary forces. In all the remaining four assertive cases, China could have acted in the same ways years or even decades before.” https://thediplomat.com/2017/12/whats-really-behind-chinese-assertiveness-in-the-south-china-sea/
South China Sea oil price is around $60, much like Brent and WTI. There might be an econ incentive, if the price inflation continues next year. https://oilprice.com/oil-price-charts#section_52

The HYSY 981 is now located off the coast of Sanya as of December 20. 
https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/home/shipid:565777/zoom:14  The Hong Kong Observatory’s 9-day forecast states: “The winter monsoon now affecting Guangdong is expected to moderate gradually in the next couple of days. Temperatures over the region will rise. A replenishment of the monsoon will affect southern China during Christmas Holidays, it will be generally fine with cool morning over the region. Besides, Tropical Cyclone Tembin will move across the southern part of the Philippines and intensify gradually in the next couple of days.” (http://www.hko.gov.hk/wxinfo/currwx/fnd.htm)  Given the location of the rig and the potential disruption from the winter monsoon, I don’t think its likely they will be moving the HYSY 981 into another country’s EEZ in the next 11 days. Plus, China has more pressing political matters such as North Korea.
I believe they may be trying to spud a well by Christmas and while NK and Israel have the stage plus the peoples air force has been harassing Taiwanese Air Defenses.

It has moved: https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:565777/mmsi:413464330/imo:9480344/vessel:HAI_YANG_SHI_YOU_981 Between Hainan and Parcels at 17.95701°  112.0332°: https://www.google.com/maps/place/17%C2%B057'25.2%22N+112%C2%B001'59.5%22E/@17.95701,108.4259402,6.31z/data=!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x0!8m2!3d17.95701!4d112.0332 Vietnam's EEZ: http://www.marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=8484

Good article from the Washington Post summarising recent developments in the South China Sea: https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/recent-developments-surrounding-the-south-china-sea/2017/11/20/dbd2d8a6-cdbb-11e7-a87b-47f14b73162a_story.html?utm_term=.a6935f35afce
HYSY 981 approximately 140 nautical miles ESE of Sanya - seems to be approaching the Paracel Islands. 
https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/home/shipid:565777/zoom:14
very unlikely,  and more so after the last meetings of the Asian Countries in Vietnam and the Philippines

Xi Jinping's visit to Vietnam: "Beijing and Hanoi agreed to manage and control their differences over South China Sea disputes and refrain from moves that would affect stability in the disputed waters, according to a joint communique released after Xi’s trip." (http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/2119868/china-vietnam-sign-cooperation-pacts-bid-thaw-ties). The article does go on to state, however, that Vietnam is looking to do deals with the U.S. and Japan in relation to natural resources in the SCS - something that China would likely not look on as favourably. 
That being said, there is just over 6 weeks left on this question and these agreements were signed on November 13. 
In other news: the Bluewhale II is undergoing final testing in the South China Sea. https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/The-Oil-Rig-Drilling-10-Miles-Under-The-Sea.html
What are the chances of moving it this late in the year? Typhoon season in progress.

The HYSY 981 hasn't moved much in the last week - https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:565777/mmsi:413464330/imo:9480344/vessel:HAI_YANG_SHI_YOU_981
Will keep tracking its movements. 
China's National Offshore Oil Corporation made a winning bid for drilling rights in Brazil - which include deepwater oil fields. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/27/business/energy-environment/brazil-oil-auction.html

Lowering for July-December.
Use of military in the South China Sea in relation to energy firms:
“Indonesia, which isn’t a claimant in the South China Sea drama but maintains an exclusive economic zone there, recently announced intentions to use its military to provide security for resource exploration activities.”
Hugo Brennan, Asia analyst at Verisk Maplecroft said: “blurring the lines between commercial and naval actives in this way raises the potential for oil and gas assets to become targets in any militarised confrontation.” 
“Even as China prevents others from tapping hydrocarbon deposits located within its nine-dash line, it's in no rush to develop those assets. That's likely because 71.2 percent of total discovered reserves within the nine-dash line are "not currently considered commercially viable," according to Brennan” 
(https://www.cnbc.com/2017/09/20/beijings-military-threats-in-south-china-sea-worrying-for-companies.html)  EIA states “the Spratly islands to have virtually no proved or probable oil reserves…however the Spratly Island territory may contain significant deposits of undiscovered hydrocarbons. Evidence suggests that most of these resources are likely located in the contested Reed Bank”
“The Paracel Island territory does not have significant discovered conventional oil and gas fields and thus has no proved or probable reserves.” https://www.eia.gov/beta/international/regions-topics.cfm?RegionTopicID=SCS
Based on this, and current oil prices, it would likely prove more economically viable for China to move an oil rig into another country’s EEZ near the Spratly Islands, rather than its current position. However, I’m not going completely to 0% for July-December as its possible China could move the HYSY 981 into Vietnamese waters for exploration activities. Although, the current oil price is not favourable for exploration activities, relative to the 2014 high of $112/b.

Hurricane season ends in mid November; and HYSY 981 is at Hainen, within distance of the 2014 test sites in the Parcel (Xishi) islands.
http://english.cntv.cn/2014/06/09/ARTI1402270009293957.shtml
Given the DPRK situation, China does not want to escalate international tensions in the area.

The HYSY 981 is currently off the coast of Hainan - close to the Vietnamese EEZ boundary, but still within China’s territorial sea. From the AMTI map you can see where China claims the boundary of its EEZ to be; given that it overlaps into Vietnams it still seems possible they will move their oil rig into what Vietnam claims as it’s EEZ. Considering the already heightened tensions in the South China Sea due to North Korea, it seems unlikely China would want to raise tensions with Vietnam too.
https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/home/shipid:565777/zoom:14
https://amti.csis.org/maritime-claims-map/
China seems to be following diplomatic route at present.

The HYSY 981 appears to be stalking the Vietnamese EEZ boundary. 
(https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:565777/mmsi:413464330/imo:9480344/vessel:HAI_YANG_SHI_YOU_981) 
Will increase probability for July - December if the rig moves west.

ASEAN communique stalls amid disagreement on South China Sea stance Mogato (2017) Aug 5, states that: Southeast Asian foreign ministers failed to release a customary communique at the end of a high-level meeting on Saturday after what diplomats said was a lack of consensus about how to refer to disputes in the South China Sea. The South China Sea has long been the most, thorny issue for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), with different opinions among its 10 members on how to address China's assertiveness and its building and heavy arming of its artificial islands in disputed waters. Philippine foreign ministry spokesman Robespierre Bolivar gave no reason for the delay and said the statement would instead be released at the end of a series of regional events hosted by Manila in the next few days. "The communique will be issued together with all the chairman's statements by the end of all the meetings," he said. ASEAN's problem in agreeing the wording highlight China's growing influence at a time of uncertainty whether the new U.S. administration will priorities relations with ASEAN, and try to check Beijing's controversial maritime activities. Diplomats from three ASEAN countries said the delay was because Vietnam, which is among four members with competing sovereignty claims with China, wanted the text to mention the need to avoid land reclamation and militarization (para. 1-6). China is extremely sensitive about ASEAN mentioning its expansion of its military capabilities on those islands and some members are concerned about possible repercussions of upsetting Beijing given its military and economic power (para.8). Three of China's seven reclaimed reefs have runways several kilometers’ long, radar, surface-to-air missiles and storage facilities for fighter jets. "It's only Vietnam holding out. Maybe, by tomorrow everything will be ironed out," said one diplomat involved in the drafting process (para. 8-10). Mogato, M. (2017). ASEAN communique stalls amid disagreement on South China Sea stance. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-asean-philippines-idUSKBN1AL05R

Lowering forecast for July-December: “Vietnam has reportedly terminated a gas-drilling expedition in a disputed area of the South China Sea, following threats from China. According to an industry source, Repsol executives were told last week by the government in Hanoi that China had threatened to attack Vietnamese bases in the Spratly Islands if the drilling did not stop.” (http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-40701121) 
Given that Vietnam withdraw on this fairly quickly after the Chinese threatened attacks it doesn’t seem likely the Chinese would then move a deep-sea rig into Vietnams EEZ. 
Looks like China will have the Philippines permission to enter their EEZ under a joint venture: 
“On July 12, a Philippines energy official said drilling at Reed Bank could resume before years end, with Manila ready to offer new blocks to investors via bidding in December. On July 25, Philippine President Duterte said the Philippines and China will enter into joint oil exploration with China in those same parts [Reed Bank] without saying when” (https://qz.com/1037896/south-china-seas-untapped-oil-and-natural-gas-back-in-focus/)

According to this map, the HYSY 981 isn't too far from the Vietnamese EEZ boundary? That was based on data received from the 9th July.
https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/home/shipid:565777/zoom:14

Vietnam drills for oil in South China Sea
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-40493277
---------------------------------------
"Vietnam may have judged that with China currently promoting its "Belt and Road" initiative to the region and encouraging other countries to agree the new Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), at the same time as it is preparing for its crucial Communist Party congress, it would be unwilling to provoke a regional crisis.
There are no obvious signs of Chinese retaliation so far but we could see a tit-for-tat response with Beijing authorizing a drilling operation in an area that Vietnam also claims. This, however, would take some time to organize."

Adding to @Rene’s comment:  “Vietnam granted Indian oil firm ONGC Videsh a two-year extension to explore oil block 128. Part of that block is in the U-shaped 'nine-dash line' which marks the vast area that China claims in the sea.” 
In response; “Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Geng Shuang said China opposes anyone “carrying out unilateral, illegal oil and gas activities in waters China has jurisdiction over. We hope the relevant country can act on the basis of maintaining regional peace and stability and not do anything to complicate the situation”  Lowering slightly for July-December period, but its possible the Chinese will retaliate - though how they do this will be time dependent. If the Chinese were to respond quickly in a physical manner, that would likely involve China’s Maritime Militia.

"So far the only casualty of Vietnam's new oil expedition has been a planned meeting of the annual Vietnam-China border defence friendship exchange. That high-level meeting between the two countries' militaries was supposed to have taken place on the same day the Deepsea Metro I began drilling. Instead, Gen Fan - who was due in Hanoi after his Madrid visit - flew home, citing problems with the "working arrangements".
Vietnam may have judged that with China currently promoting its "Belt and Road" initiative to the region and encouraging other countries to agree the new Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP), at the same time as it is preparing for its crucial Communist Party congress, it would be unwilling to provoke a regional crisis.
There are no obvious signs of Chinese retaliation so far but we could see a tit-for-tat response with Beijing authorising a drilling operation in an area that Vietnam also claims. This, however, would take some time to organise." http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-40493277

"A few days before General Fan’s Hanoi visit, Mr. Vuving said, China moved the same oil rig to a position in the South China Sea that is near the midway point between the Chinese and Vietnamese coasts, apparently seeking to pressure Vietnam to cease oil and gas exploration in disputed waters. Data from myship.com, a website affiliated with the Chinese Transport Ministry, showed that the rig has been about 70 nautical miles south of China and 120 nautical miles northeast of Vietnam over the past week."
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/21/world/asia/china-vietnam-south-china-sea.html The link to myship.com is a dead link. I did find this location on twitter: https://twitter.com/GregPoling/status/877590345063649280/photo/1

China’s economic growth so far has been strong this year and is forecast at 6.5% for 2017.  “Crude oil production is likely to recover gradually due to higher operational activities and more spending in 2017. Petrochina is planning to increase spending from $19.8bn to $22.8bn in the current year” (http://www.opec.org/opec_web/static_files_project/media/downloads/publications/OPEC%20MOMR%20May%202017.pdf). With increased spending, the probability of a deep-sea rig being put into operation increases. 
It was recently reported in a bloomberg article: “Pumping crude from seabeds thousands of feet below water is turning cheaper as producers streamline operations and prioritize drilling in core wells, according to Wood Mackenzie Ltd…Royal Dutch Shell approved a deep-water project in the Gulf of Mexico with a break even price of $40” (https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-05-30/trouble-brewing-for-opec-as-once-costly-deep-sea-oil-turns-cheap) 
That being said, despite OPEC extending cuts there are still fears that it wont be enough to reduce the glut which is weighing on oil prices. China might be put off investing large amounts into deep-water projects until the market responds to an inventory drawdown and prices go up.  Also, both the Bluewhale drilling rigs are capable of deep-sea drilling for oil and “flammable methane” and the question does not specify that the oil rig must be drilling for oil.
There is the possibility that China will move either Bluewhale 1 or 2 (when commissioned) into Reed (Recto) Bank - 50 miles west of the Philippine island of Palawan which is considered to hold a large amount of methane hydrate. (http://usa.inquirer.net/4314/china-will-declare-war-ph-drills-oil)
They have no immediate need to make other states in the region nervous.  The US is supplying everything they need for that purpose.
Affirming my time table on this.

Lowering forecast for January-June and increasing for July-December as another rig increases the probability of China moving one into another countries EEZ. 
China is adding another deep-sea rig to their fleet: "The construction of the ultra-deep water semisubmersible drilling rig, Bluewhale 2, which can mine both combustible ice and oil, will be completed in the second half of the year according to the manufacturer”.(http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/business/2017-05/26/content_29503851.htm) 
China and Vietnam have both agreed to "manage and properly control maritime disputes, not take any actions to complicate the situation or expand the dispute and maintain peace and stability in the South China Sea" http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/05/15/asia-pacific/china-vietnam-agree-keep-south-china-sea-tensions-check/#.WS3JTlK-L-Y
At the moment I don’t see the relations between China and Vietnam improving enough for China to ask for Vietnams permission to drill within their EEZ.
It seem that China is finding better opportunities to piss off others!

Lowering possibility of occurring before June 30, 2017. 
The Bluewhale 1 is being used to extract gas in the South China Sea: http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/china-extracts-gas-from-flammable-ice-mined-from-south-china-sea
Will adjust July-December probability when more information on the HYSY 981 possible contract is revealed.

Dalian Shipbuilding Industry Offshore has launched COSL's newbuild semisub rig, the Hai Yang Shi You 982. The rig is slated for delivery in Q4 this year / Q1 next year. The rig's work programme is yet to be announced. The HYSY 982 was ordered in October 2013 and is capable of drilling in 1,500 meters of water.

Reports that the HYSY 981 has been awarded a 5 month drilling contract, starting May 1st. No details of where it will be operating have been disclosed - I guess it will be the wait-and-see approach. 
Possible that this is a false report, as CNOOC said they had no comment for "market rumours". Though, oil companies are rarely willing to discuss operations. 
http://www.offshoreenergytoday.com/report-cnooc-takes-deepwater-semi-sub-hysy-981/

Lowering the possibility of it happening between January and end of June. Given the escalating tension in the South China Sea right now, I think it would be a poor move on China's part if they moved an oil rig into another countries EEZ without permission. 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-usa-idUSKBN17Q06N

The last given update of the position of he Bluewhale 1 deep sea drilling rig was on the 9th April and was located N19˚54’44” E115˚20’42”.  http://www.myshiptracking.com/?mmsi=636017220
https://www.vesselfinder.com/?imo=9684081 The HYSY 981 is still docked in Yantai

The Filipino President Duterte has said "he was open to sharing resources with Beijing in flashpoint South China Sea waters over which Manila has been given exclusive rights by an international tribunal." This is because Duterte has said the Philippines cannot afford extraction equipment. However, the Philippine Defence Chief Lorenzana said "President Duterte has drawn a red line on any reclamation by China of Scarborough Shoal." And also went on to say "Once the Chinese start exploring, putting rigs there, we'll talk to them". (http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/2081809/duterte-says-philippines-cant-afford-oil-rigs-open-sharing) - suggesting that China won't ask permission beforehand. Another article states Chinese survey ships were spotted last year near Benham Rise (Philippine territory) and Lorenzana said "I have ordered the navy that if they see this service ship this year, to start to accost them and drive them away". (http://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/2077439/philippines-very-concerned-chinese-survey-ships-enter-its)

I think the Chinese are looking for stability abroad, at least until its leadership transition in the fall. Even after that, I'm inclined to think the Chinese are not looking to rock the waters (pun intended) in the South China Sea this year. That is based on the sharp slowdown in land reclamation and that the rig could have been deployed again at any time.

I've been checking the marine traffic website, along with other websites that track vessels, for the location of the Bluewhale 1 (the new Chinese deep-sea oil rig - http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/china-launches-worlds-largest-oil-exploration-offshore-platform). According to these websites it is currently situated in the South China Sea - could be heading towards the Parcel Islands. I haven't adjusted my forecast yet  because the Bluewhale 1 is listed under the flag of Liberia. I understand ships sometimes register under different flags for tax reasons etc, but I'm not aware of oil rigs doing it - so I might not be looking at the right rig. Does anyone have any knowledge of this? 
https://www.vesselfinder.com/?imo=9684081
https://www.fleetmon.com/vessels/bluewhale-1_9684081_10689724/?language=en
http://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/home/centerx:115/centery:20/zoom:6

Currently moored at 37.59084° / 121.4005°, near coastline.  Deploying in an EEZ would be too daring and would push China's neighbor into the arms of the US just when some nations have decided to take a more conciliatory line with China. Must deploy before typhoon season, which is usually May-October but was July-December last year.

China has launched "the world's largest and deepest-operating offshore oil exploration platform" called the Bluewhale I. They say it is designed specifically for the South China Sea.  (http://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/2076179/china-launches-worlds-largest-oil-exploration-sea-platform) 
China and the Philippines seem to be trying to work together, a recent article stated "a Philippine company and the CNOOC have revived talks over an oil exploration project in the South China Sea". (http://thestandard.com.ph/business/power-technology/230553/ph-china-reviving-oil-exploration-talks.html)

I attempted to educate myself on the history and current situation. I was persuaded by a PRC response to the UNCLOS arbitration where China made claims to "historic title" in the nine dash line specifically referencing fishing rights but not oil and gas. Also seems that China's strategy and rise will be based more on getting neighbors together. The US military presence in South China Sea could alter China's strategy which seems aimed at global leadership on a number of fronts. China's opportunities to lead are enhanced as the US President moves towards nationalism. In other words, we appear to be pushing China closer to its neighbors.  I'm guessing that they will team up with the Philippines to drill, maybe even this year. https://southseaconversations.wordpress.com/2016/07/20/defining-the-post-arbitration-nine-dash-line-more-clarity-and-more-complication/
Maybe a little too dogmatic on this

They don't need this particular oil, so such a move would only be done by way of a test for either a specific competitor state or the new US administration.  In a breathtakingly short time, the new US administration has already failed a number of tests, but this one would be more precisely calibrated to see just what the response would be in terms of particular interests of the PRC.   If the Chinese government would like a more specific idea of what the new kids will do, this is not a bad way to get one.  (In this case "not a bad way" means a way likely to provide helpful information to the PRC; it may well be a bad way in the sense of lots of people getting killed.)  So this step will almost surely be taken.  For our purposes, though, timing is what counts.  Stay tuned.

Deepwater exploration (assuming this is in an undeveloped basin) is expensive business.  Therefore, companies have to spend time and money on seismic collection and other science efforts to develop meaningful prospects.  The global dry hole rate in new basins is about 95%.  The only really developed areas for the neighbors are Vietnam and a small part of the Phillipines.  China is not afraid to drill a well in its neighbor's waters.  But it is unlikely in the near-term.

Confirming previous forecast.  Chinese oil imports predicted to increase but no mention of new oil rig deployment
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-01-17/china-s-inescapable-oil-slide-is-a-record-breaking-gift-to-opec

Apologies if any of this has been mentioned before:
If China claims ownership of disputed islands such as the Paracel Islands (or what the Chinese call the Xisha islands), they’re not going to ask for permission.  The recent increase in oil prices, since the OPEC agreement, increases investment in the oil industries so this could give a good reason for China to up activity in exploration. Given that China is the largest oil importer globally, with rising oil prices it also becomes more costly for them and so they would be looking at being more energy independent.  According to an EIA report on the South China Sea, “The Paracel Island territory does not have significant discovered conventional oil and gas fields and thus has no proved or probably reserves. Geologic evidence suggests the area does not have significant potential in terms of conventional hydrocarbons.” Though it says here no “significant discovered” it does not mean that there is no oil there, but could be that it is not economically viable and the more frequently China moves into waters around the Paracel Islands, the more it will be portrayed as provocation.  The EIA "estimates the region around the Spratly islands to have virtually no proved or probable oil reserves. However the Spratly island territory may contain significant deposits of undiscovered hydrocarbons - likely located in the contested Reed Bank at the northeast end of the Spratlys, which is claimed by China, Taiwan and Vietnam" (eia.gov).  Also, China's typhoon season starts in July through September, and the peak of the storm season is in August, so it would make sense for China to get the HYSY 981 out drilling before July.
One year is normally like a blink of the eye for China. If Trump threatens China early in his term, however, China could ramp up its aggressive tendencies.

Participant countries disputing China's claim in the region include the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, Indonesia, and Taiwan (ROC). Of these, China's most contentious relationship is with Indonesia.  China is the largest investor in Malaysia, Vietnam has proclaimed that it won't build up its presence in the region (and risk provocation), Duterte is actively courting China, and Taiwan technically isn't a country. Indonesia has been only country willing to challenge China's claims using its Navy, making it ripe as a target to be used as an "example." Trump will likely decide follow his isolationist tendencies and allow China to continue to militarize the area.
China will want to see the cabinet in place before testing Trump this close to inauguration.
After 1 year, they will see Trump's effectiveness or care on this issue.

Confirming previous forecast.  
Difficult to find more recent data but from (1) in 2013 limited geological data for offshore conflict areas:
" In 2011, CNOOC offered 19 bidding blocks, mostly in the Pearl River Mouth Basin of the South China Sea. Despite several recent awards to foreign firms, CNOOC has not been able to award the majority of the blocks because of overlapping territorial claims with Vietnam and limited availability of geologic data."
1: https://www.eia.gov/beta/international/regions-topics.cfm?RegionTopicID=SCS From this 2011 map (2) of oil & gas resources it appears Vietnam (Blue Dragon) /China (Crestone) area a potential or "Alcorn study" area of Philippines close to the Spratly Islands another eventual possibility.
2: http://www.southchinasea.org/files/2011/08/EEZ-Claims-Oil-and-Gas-Resources.jpg
geopolitics will play as much a role than Chinas own regional  and resource need plans only
Wait and see will be the order of the day given geopolitical turbulence.
China is waiting to see how the Trump presidency will unfold.
Hardly any time left for the rig to be deployed this year. Mirroring @seamusfag buckets.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-southchinasea-vietnam-idUSKBN13X0WD?utm_source=applenews
This strikes me as a more likely scenario than Military Responses.
Still in port. Not sure about any new ones
Downgrading everything. It's been a while since China has done this.
Vietnam may be left out to dry by Trump and used by China as a counterpoint to the Duterte approach with respect to China vs USA influence in S China Sea
The big question is will EEZ areas continue to be the playground of the Chinese and the rest of the world just watch confused?
Recent expansions by Vietnam ups the likely-hood that China will resond
The oil price has to raise in order to the action's benefits surpass the costs.

It looks there are two views on China on this board. According to the majority, China is aggressive bully who blatantly disregards international norms and is just looking for opportune moments to push its "nine-dash" vision of the world and encroach on others' rights. Of course, there is some validity of these views in recent history. And there is another (minority) point of view. Times are changing. China cannot behave as bully anymore as other countries can gang up together and call on the US (even with Trump in power). China wants to be respected rather than feared (in contrast for example to Russia). It is the biggest economy in the world (by PPP). Its influence does not match its economy yet. So China is reverting to its traditional approach of moving slowly, building its soft power and solving its disputes one by one with neighbors through bilateral, rather than multilateral agreements. If you talk to Chinese, they would say such approach is in their culture. So far it works - Philippines and Malaysia are moving toward China. Why risk it with deep  sea oil rigs in others' EEZ? The oil is cheap now. The sea lanes are open. China is building alternatives, with its Silk Road. And Saudis are happy to send their Oil to the Chinese... As always, it is my personal view and I do not pretend to know The Truth
I don't think China is pressured to seek more conflict. They can just grab the low hanging fruit for a good while.

Google Maps is up-to-date, it has satellite images of Yantai from 2016. You can see 5 oil rigs (?) in this picture [1], one of them in a drydock. There is also some kind of ship/rig in a smaller drydock.  I'm still trying to find out if one of them is the 'notorious' HYSY 981. It should be there, according to [2]  [1] https://www.google.nl/maps/place/Yantai,+Shandong,+China/@37.5942225,121.4000245,1048m/data=!3m1!1e3!4m5!3m4!1s0x35906384d74b95c5:0x4ec649d60d6074d5!8m2!3d37.463822!4d121.447935

The Philippines has changed the game in the SCS. China will be very focused on making things work with Duterte for the next year, I think. It's very unlikely they'd give up on cooperation in less than six months. The real question is what will happen in the area disputed with Vietnam. China has been increasingly adventurous within this region.  I think it is likely that this will occur something next year.

China wants more oil and gas independence and they are committed to being the dominant player in the South China Sea. With a new deep sea drilling rig available in 2017 it is tempting to say that they will put it in disputed waters. A wild card in this is the new relationship with the Philippines. Could China possibly get permission from the other countries? Philippines and Malaysia maybe, Vietnam and Taiwan probably not unless they sense that the US is no longer a reliable ally and must make moves to accept the new power structure in the area.

Reports of rigs in disputed waters, in Q's links do not seem to be in EEZ's.  Preliminary exploration in Viet Nam's EEZ for 2014, require data analysis before further testing, so upcoming incursions are possible, given that China claims these areas are within their Parcel Island claims.  China's attempt to use bi lateral negotiations to resolve SCS disagreements, may lead to a less confrontational approach in the area. Typhoon season generally lasts from July to early November.  The 2014 testing lasted 10 weeks, so the likely timeframe for new tests may be before the July Typhoon season starts.
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/2016_Pacific_typhoon_season

The point of doing this is not actually to drill for oil, but to establish that the PRC can do it.   They will want to run a test on this principle fairly early in the next US administration.  It'll be interesting to see who the Lucky Winner is:  It was Vietnam last time, and the Philippines is taking a dive on these issues under the courageous Duterte, but there are lots of EEZs within EEZ reach.
